page.title: 08WOODLAND AROUND FARLEY
page.content: A great deal of Farley is woodland. In fact over the twelve square kilometre block, five square kilometres is woodland. Most of the woodland is coniferous and has been planted. In Bentley Wood the trees have been planted by the Forestry Commission but now it belongs to a Trust, in order to conserve the wildlife. Blackmoor Copse is ancient woodland and belongs to the Wiltshire Nature Conservancy. The wood was mentioned in the Domesday Book. It is the only area where the butterfly the Purple Emperor is protected. Farley and Brown's Copse are old woodlands. A great deal of these woods are Hazel Coppice. This is used to make hurdles, which were originally used to keep sheep in. Pitton Copse and Great Netley Copse are part of the Claredon Estate and are privately planted.
